prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA for ruining my BF’s dreams because he cheated?
Hi everyone! This is my first post, but I watch a lot of Reddit videos so I thought I might be able to get help here.
For background, my boyfriend and I have been together almost 3 years now. Things were going really well for a while, we were even supposed to get married last year. That’s when things went downhill. A month before the wedding he called it off. Since then, we fought a lot, but went to therapy and tried to work things out. Obviously, that didn’t really solve everything.
That brings us to this semester (we’re both college seniors) when shit absolutely hit the fan. Now, most semesters he takes 6 dance classes and does 2 dances for our schools company (if you hadn’t gathered, he’s a dance major). This semester he took 6 classes but also did 4 dances. He also has been taking a lot of outside volunteer work for the company. Not only does this mean he basically can’t work at all anymore, it also means when he gets home he just wants to relax because he’s exhausted. That wouldn’t be too bad if he threw away his trash, put his dishes in the sink, and put his laundry in the basket. But he doesn’t. So now I cook, clean, do laundry and dishes plus go to school full time and teach 15 hours a week.
To top it all off, I found out he cheated on me. When I confronted him about he he gave me a myriad of excuses like: I just like her because she’s skinny and I don’t really find you attractive any more (I’ve been working on losing weight but I’m recovering from anorexia so I have to go slow), if you didn’t want me to you should have just stopped me (???), and my favorite, I won’t sleep with her anymore but I just want to stay her friend because she’s funny (as a last ditch effort). When I made him block her because she showed up at our school while I was having lunch with him (she /still/ doesn’t know I’m his girlfriend), he broke his phone, then proceeded to blame me because I “made him anxious and embarrassed him”.
I’m tired. My family pays the bills and rent; he only pays for groceries. At this point, I want to kick him out.  But, any time I tell him that he has to hold his end or leave, he says he would be homeless and I would be ruining his dreams. And he’s right. He doesn’t have the money to move out and would have to move 2 hours away back home with his POS dad. I would ruin his dreams of being a professional dancer. But I also just feel drained and used, and just want to feel good about myself again.
So, TL;DR my BF called off our wedding and cheated on me, but if I kicked him out I’d ruin his whole life. 
So, WIBTA?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong here. The situation is about a relationship where the boyfriend cheated, and the author is considering ending it but feels conflicted because it might ruin his career.

First, I need to break down the key points. The boyfriend called off the wedding a year before it was supposed to happen. Then they fought a lot but went to therapy. The current semester, he's taking a lot of dance classes and doing extra work, leading to him neglecting household responsibilities. He also cheated on her, and when confronted, gave excuses like not finding her attractive anymore. She's handling all the chores, paying rent, etc., and he can't move out due to financial reasons. She's considering kicking him out but feels guilty because he might have to move back home, which would affect his dance career.

The main question is whether she's in the wrong if she does this. The user wants an answer A (yes) or B (no). 

In terms of right and wrong, cheating is generally considered a serious breach of trust in relationships. The boyfriend's excuses are pretty bad—saying he likes someone else because she's skinny and implying the author isn't attractive anymore, especially when she's in recovery for anorexia. That's not just a mistake; it's emotionally abusive. When confronted, his responses are blaming and dismissive, even breaking his phone and blaming her for his anxiety. That's a red flag.

She's doing all the work around the house, paying most of the bills, and he's contributing only groceries. She's at her breaking point, feeling drained and used. If she kicks him out because he cheated and isn't pulling his weight, isn't that justified? He's the one who cheated and isn't taking responsibility. His argument that she'd ruin his dreams seems to be a way to guilt-trip her into staying, which is manipulative.

But maybe there's a consideration about his financial situation. However, he's the one who cheated, and she's not obligated to support him financially just because he's in a vulnerable position. His actions have led to the situation, so he's responsible for the consequences. She's not the one who broke the relationship; he did by cheating. Ending the relationship isn't ruining his dreams—it's holding him accountable for his actions. 

I think the answer is B (No, the author is not in the wrong). She's justified in wanting to leave after the betrayal and lack of accountability. The boyfriend's behavior is the root of the problem here.
